poem:
**The Pollen Match**

June steps into the ring,  
a green boxer, gloves of pollen,  
dancing lightly on tender air.  
  
Lisa stands, eyelids swollen,  
her breath a ragged sigh,  
eyes streaming like riverbanks in rain.  
  
She throws no punches;  
instead, the sky taps her cheek  
with fists of bloom and sneeze,  
an endless counting down.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "‘It looks like I’ve gone 10 rounds with a boxer’: when hay fever becomes debilitating – and potentially deadly Sometimes the season starts as early as mid-April; other times it’s slower to get going. Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
